us.ihmc.euclid.referenceFrame.interfaces

Interface FixedFrameLine2DBasics

  • All Superinterfaces:
    us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.Clearable, FrameLine2DReadOnly, Line2DBasics, Line2DReadOnly, ReferenceFrameHolder, us.ihmc.euclid.interfaces.Transformable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    FrameLine2DBasics
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    FrameLine2D

    public interface FixedFrameLine2DBasics
extends FrameLine2DReadOnly, Line2DBasics
    Write and read interface for a line 2D expressed in a constant reference frame, i.e. this line is always expressed in the same reference frame.

    A line 2D represents an infinitely long line in the XY-plane and defined by a point and a direction.

    In addition to representing a Line2DBasics, a ReferenceFrame is associated to a FixedFrameLine2DBasics. This allows, for instance, to enforce, at runtime, that operations on lines occur in the same coordinate system.

    Because a FixedFrameLine2DBasics extends Line2DBasics, it is compatible with methods only requiring Line2DBasics. However, these methods do NOT assert that the operation occur in the proper coordinate system. Use this feature carefully and always prefer using methods requiring FixedFrameLine2DBasics.

      • set

        default void set(ReferenceFrame referenceFrame,
                 double pointOnLineX,
                 double pointOnLineY,
                 double lineDirectionX,
                 double lineDirectionY)
        Redefines this line with a new point and a new direction vector.
        Parameters:
        referenceFrame - the reference frame in which the given coordinates are expressed.
        pointOnLineX - the new x-coordinate of the point on this line.
        pointOnLineY - the new y-coordinate of the point on this line.
        lineDirectionX - the new x-component of the direction of this line.
        lineDirectionY - the new y-component of the direction of this line.
        Throws:
        ReferenceFrameMismatchException - if this.getReferenceFrame() and referenceFrame are not the same reference frame.
